title: About
text:
Our Mission
To conduct cutting-edge research in microbiology that contributes to the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of infectious diseases. We aim to foster excellence in research and education while promoting collaboration with national and international institutions.

title: About
text:
Research Focus Areas

Bacterial Pathogenesis: Investigating mechanisms of bacterial infection and host-pathogen interactions
Antimicrobial Resistance: Studying the emergence and spread of antibiotic-resistant bacteria and developing strategies to combat resistance
Viral Infections: Researching viral diseases prevalent in Indonesia and Southeast Asia, including emerging infectious diseases
Mycology: Exploring fungal pathogens and their clinical significance
Molecular Microbiology: Utilizing molecular techniques to understand microbial genetics and evolution
Clinical Microbiology: Improving diagnostic methods and developing evidence-based treatment protocols

title: About
text:
Our Team
Our research group consists of dedicated faculty members, postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and laboratory technicians. Each member brings unique expertise and contributes to our collaborative research environment.

title: About
text:
Biosafety Level 2 (BSL‑2) laboratories
Molecular biology facilities for PCR, sequencing, and genetic analysis
Cell culture facilities
Advanced microscopy equipment
Automated microbiology systems for clinical diagnostics

title: About
text: We collaborate with national and international research centers, hospitals, and universities to contribute to multicenter studies and global health initiatives.

title: About
text:
Supervision of undergraduate and graduate research projects
Workshops and training programs in microbiological techniques
Participation in national and international conferences
Mentorship programs for young researchers

title: About
text:
Contact Us
For more information about our research activities, collaboration opportunities, or educational programs, please contact us through the Faculty of Medicine, Universitas Indonesia.

title: Clinical Microbiology Research Group
text:
Universitas Indonesia
  
  
    
     Faculty of Medicine UI
  
  
    
     Email
  

  
  
The Microbiology Research Group at the Faculty of Medicine, Universitas Indonesia (FKUI) is dedicated to advancing knowledge in the field of microbiology through innovative research and education.





The Department of Clinical Microbiology at the Faculty of Medicine, Universitas Indonesia is organized into five specialized research groups, each focused on critical areas of microbiology and infectious diseases. These multidisciplinary teams bring together experienced researchers, clinicians, and scientists who are dedicated to advancing knowledge through innovative research, clinical practice, and education.




Bacteriology and Antimicrobial Resistance-Integrated One Health
Emerging Microbes and Infectious Diseases
Virology and Pathobiology Cancer
Diagnosis and Therapy of Fungal Infection
Pathogenomic and Cellular Mycobacteria

title: Clinical Microbiology Research Group
text: The Department of Clinical Microbiology at the Faculty of Medicine, Universitas Indonesia is organized into five specialized research groups, each focused on critical areas of microbiology and infectious diseases. These multidisciplinary teams bring together experienced researchers, clinicians, and scientists who are dedicated to advancing knowledge through innovative research, clinical practice, and education.

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Group Name: Virology and Cancer Pathobiology
Research Focus: Investigation of viral pathogens and their role in cancer pathobiology, development of viral-based cancer therapies, and molecular surveillance of oncogenic viruses.





Dr. dr. Budiman Bela, Sp.MK (K)

Title/Credentials: Doctor, PhD, Clinical Microbiology Specialist (Consultant)
Email: budiman.bela@ui.ac.id
Phone: +62 21 316 0491
Scopus Author ID: 24723637900
H-Index: 7 (Scopus)
Total Citations: 156+







Title/Credentials: Veterinary Doctor, PhD, Master in Biomedical Sciences
Specialization: Veterinary Virology, Zoonotic Viral Infections, Bacterial Sialidase Antiviral Research, Avian Influenza
Email: silvia.tri@gmail.com
Scopus Author ID: 57208952258
H-Index: 2 (Scopus)
Key Research: NanB bacterial sialidase as antiviral agent, Influenza H5N1 and H9N2 research, Clostridium perfringens applications





Title/Credentials: DEA (Diplôme d’Études Approfondies), PhD from Université d’Aix-Marseille II
Specialization: Virology, Cancer Pathobiology, Stem Cell Differentiation, Biosafety and Biorisk Management
Email: aroem.naroeni@gmail.com
Scopus Author ID: 6507663156
Affiliation: Lecturer and Researcher at PRVKP FKUI; Adjunct Faculty at Universitas Esa Unggul
Key Research: Ovarian cancer nanomedicine, Cisplatin-nanocurcumin combinations, Biorisk management implementation





Title/Credentials: Professor, Doctor, PhD, Clinical Microbiology Specialist (Consultant)
Specialization: Clinical Virology, Dengue Pathogenesis, Pediatric Infectious Diseases, Molecular Diagnostics
Email: r.fera@ui.ac.id
NIDN: 17026006
Academic Rank: Professor
Key Research: Factors associated with positive blood cultures in pediatric patients, FIEBRE study collaborator







Viral pathogenesis (Dengue, HIV, HPV, Influenza, SARS-CoV-2)
Cancer virology and oncogenesis
Molecular pathobiology and cancer diagnostics
Development of viral-based oncolytic therapies (e.g., Salmonella-based systems)
Zoonotic viral infections and avian influenza
Bacterial sialidase as antiviral agents
COVID-19 vaccine immunogenicity research







Duration: 2022 - Present
Funding: Universitas Indonesia / PUTI Pascasarjana Research Grant
Description: First in Indonesia: Engineering Salmonella bacteria to target and destroy cervical cancer cells through bacterial-mediated cancer therapy. The modified bacteria are designed to selectively infiltrate and eliminate cervical cancer cells, representing a novel immunotherapeutic approach.
Lead Researchers: Dr. Budiman Bela





Duration: 2023 - 2025
Funding: Basic Research Grant / Universitas Indonesia
Description: Investigation of the in vitro and in vivo antiviral potential of NanB bacterial sialidase from Clostridium perfringens, focusing on its ability to inhibit viral entry and replication of avian influenza H5N1 and H9N2 viruses. Studies conducted in MDCK cells and BALB/c mice models.
Lead Researchers: Dr. Silvia Tri Widyaningtyas, Dr. Budiman Bela, Prof. Amin Soebandrio





Duration: 2023 - Present
Funding: Human Cancer Research Cluster (HCRC) / NICCRAT - International Collaboration
Description: Comprehensive study of HPV genotypes in cervical cancer and other virus-associated malignancies across Indonesian populations. Focus on molecular characterization, epidemiological surveillance, and development of improved early detection methods and vaccine strategies. Part of the Female Cancer Program in collaboration with international partners.
International Partners: University of Nottingham (UK), Leiden University (Netherlands)





Duration: 2020 - 2024
Funding: Universitas Indonesia Innovation Grant
Description: Development of DNA vaccine expressing SARS-CoV-2 VLP (Virus-Like Particles) and evaluation of antibody induction in C57BL/6 mice. Comparative analysis of mRNA and inactivated COVID-19 vaccines in People Living with HIV (PLWH), assessing IL-2, IFN-γ, and anti-RBD spike antibody responses.






Widyaningtyas, S.T., Bela, B., et al. (2025). In vitro antiviral activity of NanB bacterial sialidase against influenza virus. Avian Pathology, 54(1), 96-107. DOI: 10.1080/03079457.2024.2386315
Silaen, O.S.M., Widyaningtyas, S.T., et al. (2025). Potential of Clostridium perfringens sialidase as a novel antiviral agent against avian influenza H5N1 infection in BALB/c mice. Comparative Immunology, Microbiology and Infectious Diseases, 121, 102373.
Ibrahim, R.F., et al. (2025). Factors associated with positive blood cultures in children in nine countries: a secondary analysis of the FIEBRE study. BMJ Global Health, 10(10), e020448.
Amanah, A., Bela, B., Widyaningtyas, S.T., et al. (2024). Evaluation of the Effect of mRNA and Inactivated SARS-CoV-2 Vaccines on the Levels of Cytokines IL-2, IFN-γ, and Anti-RBD Spike SARS-CoV-2 Antibodies in People Living with HIV (PLWH). Biomedicines, 12(9), 2115.
Naroeni, A., et al. (2024). Potensi Virus RNA Sebagai Ancaman Penyakit Emerging dan Reemerging: Strategi Pencegahan dan Pengendalian Infeksi. UI Publishing (Book Chapter).
Syahruddin, E., … Bela, B., et al. (2022). TP53 and EGFR Mutational Status in Thymoma: A Genetic Sequencing Study. Asian Pacific Journal of Cancer Prevention, 23(1), 109-114.





Patent Granted (2024): “Antigen Rekombinan Berbasis Epitop Multipel dari Poliprotein Core, NS3, NS4A, NS4AB, dan NS5A untuk Deteksi Infeksi Virus Hepatitis C (HCV)” - Dr. Silvia Tri Widyaningtyas, Dr. Budiman Bela, Dian Amirulloh. Patent No: P00201904453. Granted: 21/02/2024.
Patent Granted (2024): “Antigen Rekombinan Envelope gp125-gp36 HIV-2 yang Dimanfaatkan dalam Uji Diagnostik HIV-2 Berbasis Pendeteksian Antibodi Spesifik Envelope HIV-2” - Dr. Budiman Bela, Fathurrohim, Dr. Silvia Tri Widyaningtyas. Patent No: S00201910806. Granted: 12/02/2024.





Domestic: Universitas Esa Unggul (teaching and research collaboration), RSUPN Dr. Cipto Mangunkusumo (RSCM - clinical trials and patient samples), PT PathGen Diagnostik Teknologi (diagnostic development), CV Abiramalab Indonesia (laboratory services), Indonesian Institute of Sciences (LIPI - biosecurity workshop 2018), Eijkman Institute for Molecular Biology
International: University of Nottingham (UK) - NICCRAT (Nottingham-Indonesia Cervical Cancer Research and Training), Osaka University (Japan - virology research), Leiden University (Netherlands - Female Cancer Program), Australian Plant Biosecurity Science Foundation (biosecurity bilateral workshop), Mico BioMed Co. Ltd (Korea - diagnostic kit development)





Virology and Cancer Pathobiology Research Center (PRVKP / Pusat Riset Virologi dan Kanker Patologi): State-of-the-art specialized laboratory equipped for viral culture, cell line maintenance (including MDCK, HT29, SKOV3 cells), molecular oncology research, and biosafety level 2 work. Facilities include PCR machines, cell culture equipment, flow cytometry, and molecular biology instrumentation. Located within Faculty of Medicine, Universitas Indonesia.
BSL-2 Facility: Biocontainment facilities suitable for handling infectious viral agents including influenza viruses, HIV, SARS-CoV-2, and conducting viral propagation studies. Equipped with biosafety cabinets, negative pressure rooms, and appropriate waste management systems.
Collaborative Laboratory Access: Through institutional partnerships, the group has access to BSL-3 facilities for high-risk pathogen research, advanced imaging facilities, animal facilities for in vivo studies (BALB/c and C57BL/6 mice), and clinical sample collection through RSCM.





The group provides training in biosafety, biosecurity, and biorisk management
Supervises doctoral (S3) and master’s (S2) students through the Biomedical Sciences program
Regular workshops and seminars on emerging viral threats
Participated in WHO mRNA Technology Transfer Programme (November 2023)





Office Location: Virology and Cancer Pathobiology Research Center (PRVKP), Department of Microbiology, Faculty of Medicine Universitas Indonesia, Jl. Pegangsaan Timur No. 16, Jakarta Pusat 10320, Indonesia
Office Phone: +62 21 316 0491
Group Email: mikrobiologi-fku@ui.ac.id
Alternative Contact: office@fk.ui.ac.id, humas@fk.ui.ac.id
Website: https://research.fk.ui.ac.id/krl/kr/profil_kr/41/442

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Group Name: Diagnosis and Therapy of Fungal Infection
Research Focus: Advanced diagnostic methods and therapeutic approaches for fungal infections, with a focus on invasive mycoses, antifungal resistance, and opportunistic fungal pathogens.

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Research Areas

Fungal diagnostics (Molecular and Serological)
Antifungal therapy and resistance mechanisms
Mycology research (Invasive Candidiasis, Pneumocystis, Dermatophytes)
Development of natural antifungal agents

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Current Projects

National Guidelines for Invasive Candidiasis

Duration: 2023 - 2024
Funding: Indonesian Pulmonary Mycoses Centre (IPMC) / Professional Societies
Brief description: Development of the first national consensus and clinical practice guidelines for the diagnosis and management of invasive candidiasis in Indonesia.

Antifungal Potential of Moringa oleifera against Candida albicans

Duration: 2023 - 2025
Funding: Universitas Indonesia / Domestic Research Grant
Brief description: Investigation of the efficacy of Moringa oleifera leaf extracts as a natural antiseptic and antifungal agent against pathogenic Candida species.

Molecular Detection of Opportunistic Fungi in Immunocompromised Patients

Duration: 2022 - Present
Funding: Departmental/Faculty Grant
Brief description: Surveillance and molecular characterization of opportunistic fungi, including Pneumocystis jirovecii, in HIV/AIDS and other immunocompromised patient populations.

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Recent Publications

Tjampakasari, C.R., Kiranasari, A., & Baswara, R.M.K. (2025). Potential of Moringa oleifera (M. oleifera) Leaf Extract as an Antiseptic against Candida albicans using Percentage Kill Test. Majalah Obat Tradisional, 30(2), 211-217. Google Scholar
Rozaliyani, A., … Rosana, Y., et al. (2024). Expert Panel Recommendations on the Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Diagnosis and Management of Invasive Candidiasis in Indonesia. Acta Medica Indonesiana, 56(2). PubMed
Tjampakasari, C.R., et al. (2024). Infeksi Bakteri Langka Chromobacterium violaceum Pada Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD). Kesehatan Kreatif: Jurnal Riset Kesehatan Inovatif, 6(1), 1-14. Google Scholar
Gultom, D.A., Rosana, Y., et al. (2024). Development of multiplex-PCR assay for rapid detection and identification of azithromycin resistance mutations. Medical Journal of Indonesia. MJI

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Research Areas

Antimicrobial resistance mechanisms
Bacterial pathogenesis
One Health approach to infectious diseases
Clinical bacteriology and diagnostics

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Current Projects

Genomic Surveillance of Antimicrobial Resistance in Indonesia

Duration: 2024 - Present
Funding: Ministry of Health / WHO / National Grants
Brief description: Implementation of Whole Genome Sequencing (WGS) to characterize multidrug-resistant organisms (MDROs) across clinical and environmental settings in Indonesia, contributing to the GLASS surveillance system.

Bacteriophage Characterization for Therapeutic Applications

Duration: 2023 - Present
Funding: Hibah PUTI UI / Domestic Research Grant
Brief description: Morphological and genomic analysis of local bacteriophages (e.g., Drulisvirus) targeting high-priority pathogens like Klebsiella pneumoniae and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

One Health Analysis of Zoonotic Bacterial Transmission

Duration: 2023 - 2025
Funding: International Collaboration Grant / Wellcome Trust
Brief description: Investigation of AMR transmission pathways between livestock, environment, and human populations, focusing on pathogens such as E. coli and Salmonella spp.

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Recent Publications

Saharman, Y.R., et al. (2025). Morphological and genomic analysis of Drulisvirus targeting Klebsiella pneumoniae. Frontiers in Bacteriology.
Gach, M.W., … Karuniawati, A., et al. (2024). Antimicrobial resistance among common bacterial pathogens in Indonesia: a systematic review. The Lancet Regional Health - Southeast Asia, 26, 100414.
Prasetyo, D.S., et al. (2024). Bacterial Identification and Sensitivity Testing from Clinical Isolates. Al-Hayat: Journal of Biology and Applied Biology, 7(1), 23-34.
Tania, T., … Sudarmono, P., et al. (2024). Current Understanding of Mycobacterium tuberculosis Drug Resistances and Diagnostics in Indonesia: A Review. Journal of Global Antimicrobial Resistance (Referenced contribution).

title: Research Group Profile
text:

Domestic: RSUPN Dr. Cipto Mangunkusumo, Indonesian Association of Clinical Microbiologists (PAMKI), Universitas Mataram, Universitas Airlangga
International: Erasmus University Medical Center (Netherlands), University of Oxford (UK), Osaka University (Japan), World Health Organization (WHO)

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Resources and Facilities

Clinical Microbiology Laboratory: Equipped with VITEK 2 Compact for automated identification and susceptibility testing, BACTEC FX for blood culture, and biosafety cabinets for handling infectious agents.
Molecular Biology and Genomic Facility: Facilities for PCR, Real-time PCR, and Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS) analysis including MinION (Nanopore) sequencing platforms for genomic surveillance.

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Research Areas

Emerging infectious diseases (Dengue, HIV, SARS-CoV-2)
Microbial surveillance and molecular epidemiology
Pathogen characterization (Genotyping, Drug Resistance)
Gut microbiome and host immune response
Vaccine and diagnostic kit development

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Current Projects

Gut Microbiota Profile in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus Patients

Duration: 2024 - 2025
Funding: Hibah PUTI UI / Domestic Grant
Brief description: Investigation of the correlation between clinical characteristics, anxiety/depression, and gut microbiota profiles in SLE patients.

Characterization of Probiotic Candidates from Indonesian Fermented Milk

Duration: 2023 - 2025
Funding: Ministry of Research and Technology / BRIN
Brief description: Molecular characterization and safety assessment of Lactococcus lactis strains isolated from “Dadih” for potential oral probiotic use.

Development of Dengue Detection Kit and Antiviral Therapies

Duration: 2023 - Present
Funding: Academia-Industry Innovation Grant (with PT Konimex)
Brief description: Collaborative research to develop high-sensitivity diagnostic kits for Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever and explore novel antiviral compounds.

title: Research Group Profile
text:

Gebrina, M., … Dewi, B.E., Yasmon, A., et al. (2025). Patients with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus with Anxiety or Depression: Clinical Characteristics, Food Intake, and Gut Microbiota Profile. Acta Medica Indonesiana, 57(3), 295-305.
Rosana, Y., … Yasmon, A., et al. (2024). Antimicrobial Susceptibility Pattern and Molecular Characteristics of Multidrug-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae in Jakarta, Indonesia. Iranian Journal of Medical Microbiology, 18(4), 238-246.

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Resources & Facilities

Molecular Virology Laboratory: Equipped for viral culture, neutralization assays, and molecular detection of emerging viruses (Dengue, HIV, CMV).
Microbiome & Metagenomics Unit: Facilities for NGS-based microbiome analysis and bioinformatics processing at department of Microbiology - Virology & Molecular Laboratory.

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Research Areas

Mycobacterial genomics and molecular epidemiology
Cellular pathogenesis and host immune response to TB
Tuberculosis drug resistance (MDR/XDR-TB) mechanisms
Vaccine development and efficacy biomarkers (e.g., MGIA)
Non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) characterization

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Current Projects

Mycobacterial Growth Inhibition Assay (MGIA) as a Vaccine Efficacy Biomarker

Duration: 2023 - 2025
Funding: Universitas Indonesia / National Research Grant
Brief description: Validation of MGIA to evaluate the biological activity and protective efficacy of novel tuberculosis vaccine candidates (e.g., pcDNA3.1-rpfD).

Genomic Analysis of Pyrazinamide Resistance in M. tuberculosis

Duration: 2023 - 2024
Funding: Domestic Research Grant
Brief description: Whole-genome sequencing analysis of pncA, rpsA, and panD genes to characterize resistance mechanisms in Indonesian M. tuberculosis isolates.

TB Lineage Distribution and Drug Resistance Profiling

Duration: 2023 - Present
Funding: International Collaboration / Faculty Grant
Brief description: Study determining the association between M. tuberculosis lineages (using WGS) and phenotypic resistance to new anti-TB drugs like bedaquiline and linezolid.

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Recent Publications

Rukmana, A., Nurfadillah, M., Gozali, C., & Kiranasari, A. (2024). Genome sequencing analysis of the pncA, rpsA and panD genes responsible for pyrazinamide resistance of Mycobacterium tuberculosis from Indonesian isolates. Tropical Medicine and International Health, 29(11), 964-970.
Andriansjah, et al. (2024). Latent Tuberculosis: Interaction of Mycobacterium tuberculosis with Macrophages. EKSAKTA: Berkala Ilmiah Bidang MIPA, 25(1), 69-80.
Nurfadillah, M., … Andriansjah, et al. (2024). Mycobacterium tuberculosis Lineage Distribution Using Whole Genome Sequencing and Bedaquiline, Clofazimine, and Linezolid Phenotypic Profile Resistance Among Rifampicin-Resistant Isolates From West Java, Indonesia. Pharmaceutical Sciences and Research, 11(1).
Scientific TPP Development Group (Contributors: Andriansjah, et al.). (2025). WHO target product profile for TB detection at peripheral settings: 2024 update. PLOS Global Public Health, 5(6), e0004612.

title: Research Group Profile
text:
Resources & Facilities

Mycobacteriology Laboratory (BSL-2/BSL-3): Facilities equipped for TB culture (LJ and MGIT), drug susceptibility testing, and safe handling of infectious mycobacteria.
Genomic Sequencing Unit: Access to Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS) platforms for whole-genome sequencing and molecular surveillance.

title: About
text:
Our research group consists of dedicated faculty members, postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and laboratory technicians.



Biosafety Level 2 (BSL‑2) laboratories
Molecular biology facilities for PCR, sequencing, and genetic analysis
Cell culture facilities
Advanced microscopy equipment
Automated microbiology systems for clinical diagnostics




We collaborate with national and international research centers, hospitals, and universities to contribute to multicenter studies and global health initiatives.




Supervision of undergraduate and graduate research projects
Workshops and training programs in microbiological techniques
Participation in national and international conferences
Mentorship programs for young researchers
